instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 1.7v
threads.message:
Not liquid damaged (or very well cleaned)
Green light and pp3v42 present. 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 1.7v  with 0v volts to ground in diode mode

Removed fuses F7040 / 7041 short is on PIN2
Pin 1 with fuses removed is 12.56v so generation is working




Injected some voltage into pin2 got to 4.5v @ 8amp
CPU got warm,
<CAPACITOR>C7242</CAPACITOR> was hot 
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> diode mode to ground was 0v (measured 1.4v on another board)
Removed the following components checking each time to see if short was gone

<CAPACITOR>C7242</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7282</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7280</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7270</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7241</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7281</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7240</CAPACITOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7200</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7283</CAPACITOR>

Still shorted to ground in diode mode. Cannot find anything else getting hot. I'm always cautious injecting voltage, should i raise it higher ?
I suspect CPU shorted to ground pulling these low or a short in the board but would appreciate and insight!  Thanks,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 1.7v
threads.message: Yup CPU is probably already dead by now. Shorted <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>/30/50. Replace the shorted FET and the driver it is connected to, but CPU is most likely dead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 1.7v
threads.message: Thank you Duke.  <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR> pin 4 was part of the problem (burnt underneath) - short follows back through <TRANSISTOR>Q7551</TRANSISTOR> pins 1/2 - removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7551</TRANSISTOR>. Short still present on pads 7/8 - assuming CPU is very dead
